title: v1.17.0
body:
<!--
Before submitting a PR, please read http://deno.land/manual/contributing

1. Give the PR a descriptive title.

  Examples of good title:
    - fix(std/http): Fix race condition in server
    - docs(console): Update docstrings
    - feat(doc): Handle nested reexports

  Examples of bad title:
    - fix #7123
    - update docs
    - fix bugs

2. Ensure there is a related issue and it is referenced in the PR text.
3. Ensure there are tests that cover the changes.
4. Ensure `cargo test` passes.
5. Ensure `./tools/format.js` passes without changing files.
6. Ensure `./tools/lint.js` passes.
-->

title: feat(fetch): Support abort reasons in fetch
body:
The spec PR for this (whatwg/fetch#1343) hasn't been finalized yet because some questions regarding service worker integration are not settled yet, but since that is not relevant to Deno and everything else seems settled, and it seems best to not wait for another Deno version to support abort reasons in the fetch API.

body:
This aligns all of the error messages, and makes falsey comparisons
more strict.

title: feat(ext/crypto): support importing ECSDA and ECDH
body:
importKey implemented for ECDSA and ECDH, extracted from #13013 with modifications
- pkcs8 : curve P-256 only
- spki : curves P-256 and P-384
- jwk : 
    public key - curves P-256 and P-384
    private key - curve P-256 only

Restrictions on to P-384 curve due to lack of support in p384 crate.

title: fix(ext/net): make unix and tcp identical on close
body:
std/http/server knows how to handle "Listener has been closed"
exceptions but not "operation canceled" errors.

Make "unix" listen sockets throw the same exception as "tcp" listen
sockets when the socket is closed and has a pending accept operation.

There is still a discrepancy when multiple accept requests are posted
but that's probably a less visible issue and something for another day.

Fixes #13033

title: fix(test): wait for inspector session in side modules
body:
Fixes #12584

<!--
Before submitting a PR, please read http://deno.land/manual/contributing

1. Give the PR a descriptive title.

  Examples of good title:
    - fix(std/http): Fix race condition in server
    - docs(console): Update docstrings
    - feat(doc): Handle nested reexports

  Examples of bad title:
    - fix #7123
    - update docs
    - fix bugs

2. Ensure there is a related issue and it is referenced in the PR text.
3. Ensure there are tests that cover the changes.
4. Ensure `cargo test` passes.
5. Ensure `./tools/format.js` passes without changing files.
6. Ensure `./tools/lint.js` passes.
-->
This the first time I've ever worked with rust so apologies if this a terrible PR.
All tests passed locally except for `test_respect_cache_revalidates` which was already failing without this change.

One thing I was a bit worried about was that this change would cause multiple breaks every time a new module is loaded. But I couldn't find any case where this happens.

Also, should a new test case for this specific issue be added? I couldn't find any existing tests checking for the inspector like this, so I'm not sure I'm capable of writing such a test case.

title: fix(core): improve error on invalid op id
body:
```
> Deno.core.opSync(undefined, 1, 1);
Uncaught TypeError: invalid op id: received `undefined` instead of an integer.
This error is often caused by a typo in an op name, or not calling
JsRuntime::sync_ops_cache() after JsRuntime initialization.
    at Object.opSync (deno:core/01_core.js:149:27)
    at <anonymous>:2:11
>
```

Closes https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/12919

title: fix(ext/web): set location undefined when `--location` is not specified
body:
Currently `globalThis.location` throws an error when `--location` is not specified. This behavior is inconvenient if a script does the feature detection like `typeof window.location` ([type-detect](https://npm.im/type-detect) is an example of such a script)

This PR changes it to return `undefined` for `window.location` when `--location` is not specified.

closes #12969
previous version: #10828

title: tests: deflake crypto InvalidIntializationVector
body:
Use fixed data that is known to error as the test intends.

Closes #13039

title: fix(watch): mitigate race condition between file write by other process and watch read
body:
Fixes #13035 and see there for details.

In summary, this mitigates reading from a file while it is still being written to. The mitigation here is to actually do a debounce instead of what looked like a throttle, but was called a debounce (maybe I'm misreading the code or don't know my definitions though :P). This also seems to have improved the test flakiness as I can run the tests a bunch of times now and they don't fail in WSL whereas previously they would fail quite often.

title: chore: place `@deprecated` tag after documentation block
body:
The way JSDoc tags work, once a tag is encountered, the text associated with the tag is everything up to the next tag, so all tags should come _after_ the documentation block associated with the entity.  This is consistent with how the likes of vscode and other parse tags, including now `deno_doc`.

This will fix issues where the documentation block is not appearing for certain entries in `doc.deno.land` because only the doc block is being displayed in a listing (along with just the `deprecated` tag).

title: refactor(ext/crypto): clean up rust side importKey
body:
This commit cleans up the Rust side of `import_key` by using a bunch of
enums instead of structs with "type" and "data" fields.

This commit does add some duplicated code for the time being, because
a lot of the other ops still need to get the same cleanup treatment.

This is an alternative to the Rust side changes in #13027.

title: fix: op_set_exit_code
body:
Fixes "op_set_exit_code" by sharing a single "Arc<AtomicI32>" between
all workers (via "op state") instead of having a "global" value stored in 
"deno_runtime" crate. As a consequence setting an exit code is always 
scoped to a tree of workers, instead of being overridable if there are
multiple worker tree (like in "deno test --jobs" subcommand).

Refactored "cli/main.rs" functions to return "Result<i32, AnyError>" instead
of "Result<(), AnyError>" so they can return exit code.

Ref https://github.com/denoland/deno/pull/12938

title: refactor(ext/crypto): clean up `exportKey` logic
body:
This commit de-duplicates and cleans up some logic in `exportKey`. There
are no functional changes in this commit (just moves code around).

title: refactor(ext/crypto): clean up `importKey` logic
body:
This commit de-duplicates and cleans up some logic in `importKey`. There
are no functional changes in this commit (just moves code around).

title: refactor(ext/crypto): various cleanups in js code
body:
As per request @lucacasonato in #12022. 

Refac covers:
1) Move importKey(jwt) for symmetric-keys to Rust, using `fn decode_b64url()`

2) Use enum `ImportExportKeyData` and related `pub struct`s to distinguish raw/jwk import data. Will be extended for RSA and EC JWK imports.

3) Move common js code to `function importKeyRSA(...)`

4) Added importkey for ECDH(raw) and moved common code to `function importKeyEC(...)`

5) Standardize use of `type`/`keyType`/`format` in key structures.
 - includes `read_rsa_public_key()` from #12921, along with validation of `r#type` where necessary
 
6) Cleanup, 
 - use const/alias `algorithmName` for `normalizedAlgorithm.name`
 - use const/alias for `namedCurve` and 'keyType'
 - use short-form to build js hashes, where possible, for example `{ format, namedCurve, ... }`

body: Closes #12944

title: feat(lsp): registry suggestion cache respects cache headers
body:
Fixes #9931

Effectively this adds a "cache strategy" to the file fetcher to respect the headers of the cached response, and the LSP registry cache is the only instance of file fetcher that uses this strategy. It isn't a 100% compliant, in the sense that we a) cache in memory per session, irrespective of headers and b) we will always persist a response to the cache, even if the headers tell us not to.  Now though for the registry cache, when we go to access that cache, we will respect any headers we received and only use the cached value if it was valid. We will still only do it once per "session" though.

I have tested it locally and it works, but wanted to get any feedback on it before I flesh out all the unit tests, specially from @lucacasonato as you probably have the strongest opinions.

title: refactor(cli): Use GraphData for check and emit
body:
Fixes #12803.
Fixes #12805.

- fix: Module graph errors show referrer info in all cases.
- fix: Module graph errors for type declaration files (`/// <reference types="..." />`, `X-TypeScript-Types`) are properly reported. They can be suppressed with `--no-check`.
- fix: Module graph errors for config file imports (`"jsxImportSources"`) are properly reported.
- TS emits are no longer stored in `ProcState::graph_data` memory. They are requested only once-per-module-per-runtime by V8, which also stores them, so they aren't useful to keep around.
- TS sources are now stored in `ProcState::graph_data` memory. These are a lot more useful to have in many short-circuiting cases.
- In `ProcState::prepare_module_load`, `createGraph()` is given a proxy loader which gives `None` for any module which is already in `ProcState::graph_data` and returns a partal graph. That means their resources aren't reloaded and their dependency branches aren't revisited when building the graph. This case had been hit for any non-statically-analyzable dynamic imports which import any existing dependencies. Performance should be drastically improved for HMR cases and other applications.
- `emit::check_and_maybe_emit()` and `tsc::exec()` are changed to take `GraphData` instead, since they may be have been given a partial graph.
- `GraphData` (now in `cli/graph_util.rs`) is extended a lot to fulfill these new roles. It reimplementes a lot of logic from `deno_graph` to work with composite graphs, hence the LOC diff.

title: refactor: cli doesn't need to depend on deno_tls
body: plus some other small refactors

title: fix(core): Fix typo in no-pending-ops error message
body: Fixes https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/12947

title: [v1.16] fix(test): Improve reliability of `deno test`'s op sanitizer with tim…
body:
…ers (#12934)

Although not easy to replicate in the wild, the `deno test` op sanitizer
can fail when there are intervals that started before a test runs, since
the op sanitizer can end up running in the time between the timer op for
an interval's run resolves and the op for the next run starts.

This change fixes that by adding a new macrotask callback that will run
after the timer macrotask queue has drained. This ensures that there is
a timer op if there are any timers which are unresolved by the time the
op sanitizer runs.

title: [v1.16] fix(workers): Make `worker.terminate()` not immediately kill the isol…
body:
…ate (#12831)

Due to a bug in V8, terminating an isolate while a module with top-level
await is being evaluated would crash the process. This change makes it
so calling `worker.terminate()` will signal the worker to terminate at
the next iteration of the event loop, and it schedules a proper
termination of the worker's isolate after 2 seconds.

title: feat(crypto): support `importKey` in SPKI format
body:
Work towards https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/11690.

This is a good milestone. Now, there is a key format that can be both imported and exported for RSA. This wasn't the case before, and it was a real blocker to [implement an authorization server in Deno](https://twitter.com/yacinehmito/status/1463260017906364425?s=20).

title: feat(runtime): add op_set_exit_code
body:
Set the exit code to use if none is provided to Deno.exit(), or when
Deno exits naturally.

Needed for process.exitCode Node compat. Paves the way for #12888.

title: feat(core): intercept unhandled promise rejections
body:
Provide a programmatic means of intercepting rejected promises without a
.catch() handler. Needed for Node compat mode.

Also do a first pass at uncaughtException support because they're
closely intertwined in Node. It's like that Frank Sinatra song:
you can't have one without the other.

Stepping stone for #7013.

title: refactor: add deno_fetch::Options for init
body:
[`deno_fetch::init`](https://docs.rs/deno_fetch/0.50.0/deno_fetch/fn.init.html) has a lot of parameters and generic on two types that keeps expanding over time. This refactor adds `deno_fetch::Options` struct for more clearly defining the various parameters.

I'm doing this because in a follow up PR, I want to add yet another configuration option to `init()`.

title: feat(wasm): Support `WebAssembly.instantiateStreaming` for file fetches
body:
Fetching of local files, added in #12545, returns a response with no headers, including the `Content-Type` header. This currently makes it not work with the WebAssembly streaming APIs, which require the response to have a content type of `application/wasm`.

Since the only way to obtain a `Response` object with a non-empty `url` field is via `fetch()`, this change changes the content type requirement to only apply to responses whose url has the `file:` scheme.

title: fix(cli): fix slow test, unbreak ci
body:
Reduce the number of iterations from 1,024 to 128.

On my big bruiser of a desktop machine it already takes up close to a
minute to complete when nothing else is running so no way it's going to
finish in the allotted time on the CI.

The fact that the test used to pass may be indicative of a performance
regression somewhere but it's not clear to me when or where that would
have been introduced.

Fixes #12887.

title: feat(core): Add ability to "ref" and "unref" pending ops
body:
This commit adds an ability to "ref" or "unref" pending ops.

Up to this point Deno had a notion of "async ops" and "unref async ops";
the former keep event loop alive, while the latter do not block event loop
from finishing. It was not possible to change between op types after 
dispatching, one had to decide which type to use before dispatch.

Instead of storing ops in two separate "FuturesUnordered" collections,
now ops are stored in a single collection, with supplemental "HashSet"
storing ids of promises that were "unrefed".

Two APIs were added to "Deno.core":
- "Deno.core.refOp(promiseId)" which allows to mark promise id 
to be "refed" and keep event loop alive (the default behavior)
- "Deno.core.unrefOp(promiseId)" which allows to mark promise 
id as "unrefed" which won't block event loop from exiting

Closes https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/12745

TODO:
- [x] metrics for unrefed ops (I think that unrefing ops should decrement `ops_dispatched_async` and increment `ops_dispatched_async_unref`, though it seems overly complicated)
- [x] cleanup handling of finished ops (remove `AsyncOpIterator`?)
- [x] add `id` field to promises returned from `Deno.core.opcallAsync`
- [x] add `Deno.core.ref(...promiseIds)` and `Deno.core.unref(...promiseIds)`

title: chore: speed up compat tests
body:
This commit speeds up compat tests by using local copy of "deno_std"
instead of downloading it from https://deno.land for each test.
Additionally type checking is skipped.

Depends on https://github.com/denoland/deno/pull/12883

title: compat: support compat mode in REPL
body:
This commit introduces "ProcState::maybe_resolver" field, which
stores a single instance of resolver for the whole lifetime of the
process, instead of creating these resolvers for each creation
of module graph. As a result, this resolver can be used in fallback
case where graph is not constructed (REPL, loading modules using
"require") unifying resolution logic.

Closes https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/12628
Closes https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/12872

title: fix(lsp): lsp should respect include/exclude files in format config
body:
Also changes it so the LSP sticks with module specifiers in the config file. I ran into an issue on CI with Mac where it was canonicalizing the file path of the config file and causing issues because now the config file was at a "different place" relative to potentially open files that aren't necessarily on the file system.

Closes #12865
Closes #12877
